bestBHT.bht: During Paul's intended departure, there was a significant disturbance known as the Way, which seemed to designate the new religion of Christianity. This phrase, used to describe the disciples of Christ before the term Christian was widely used, caused no small stir. The doctrines and ordinances of the Gospel, the way of God, had a powerful impact, prevailing and drawing numerous followers who embraced the Christian faith.

Albert Barnes: No small stir - No little excitement, disturbance, or tumult.
Respecting the doctrines of Christianity which Paul preached.
Marvin Vincent: The way. See on ch. Acts 9:2.
John Calvin: But in Demetrius it appeareth what a hurtful plague covetousness is. For one man, for his own gain’s sake, is not afraid − to trouble a whole city with sedition.
They fight not so much for the altars as for the fires, to wit, that they may have hot kitchens. They can well wink at filthy blasphemies against God, so they lack nothing of their revenues.

And as for those who, through ignorance or error, are fallen unto any ungodly occupation, or are entangled in any other impure and wicked kind of life, let them, notwithstanding, beware of such sacrilegious rashness.
Philip Schaff: The way’ seems to have been a term in the Christian phraseology of the first days used familiarly as a term signifying the disciples of Christ.
Prior to the general acceptance of the term ‘Christian,' it served as a convenient mutual designation by which the disciples could describe themselves.
Many evidently preferred it to the opprobrious epithet of the ‘Nazarenes.
Archibald T. Robertson: No small stir (ταραχος ουκ ολιγος). Same phrase in Acts 12:18 and nowhere else in the N.T. Litotes.
Concerning the Way (περ της οδου). See this phrase for Christianity in Acts 9:2; Acts 19:9; Acts 24:22 which see, like the 'Jesus Way' of the Indians.
Paul as a Roman citizen could not be thrown to wild beasts, but he so pictured the violent opponents of Christ in Ephesus.
John Gill: The Syriac version reads, 'the way of God'; and the Vulgate Latin version, 'the way of the Lord': that is, the Christian religion, and the doctrines and ordinances of the Gospel.
The Christian religion...which the saints were directed to walk in.
The Gospel...which mightily grew and prevailed, and which such numbers embraced.

bhtAttempts.bht: During the time of Paul's proposed departure, there was a significant commotion and disturbance regarding Christianity, known as the Way. This term seemed to carry a specific connotation for the new religion, as seen in Acts 9:2. The phrase no small stir illustrates the intense excitement and disturbance caused by the preaching of Paul and the doctrines of Christianity. It was a way of referring to the disciples of Christ before the term Christian gained widespread acceptance. The followers of Jesus preferred this label over the derogatory term Nazarenes. The way of God, the Christian religion, and the Gospel had a profound impact as it grew and prevailed, attracting numerous believers.

During Paul's intended departure, there was a significant disturbance known as the Way, which seemed to designate the new religion of Christianity. This phrase, used to describe the disciples of Christ before the term Christian was widely used, caused no small stir. The doctrines and ordinances of the Gospel, the way of God, had a powerful impact, prevailing and drawing numerous followers who embraced the Christian faith.

During the time of Paul's proposed departure, there was a significant commotion and disturbance regarding Christianity, known as the Way. This term seemed to carry a specific connotation for the new religion, as seen in Acts 9:2. The phrase no small stir illustrates the intense excitement and disturbance caused by the preaching of Paul and the doctrines of Christianity. It was a way of referring to the disciples of Christ before the term Christian gained widespread acceptance. The followers of Jesus preferred this label over the derogatory term Nazarenes. The way of God, the Christian religion, and the Gospel had a profound impact as it grew and prevailed, attracting numerous believers.

During Paul's proposed departure, the intense disturbance caused by the doctrines of Christianity, known as the Way, cannot be understated. This term carried a specific connotation for the new religion and served as an earlier designation before the widespread use of Christian. The disciples of Christ preferred this label over the derogatory Nazarenes. The way of God, the Christian religion, and the Gospel had a profound impact, growing and prevailing, attracting a multitude of believers.

During the time of Paul's proposed departure, the commotion and disruption caused by the preaching of Christianity, referred to as the Way, cannot be underestimated. This specific term denoted the new religion and was a preferred label for the disciples of Christ before the emergence of the term Christian. The phrase no small stir emphasizes the significant agitation and fervor generated by Paul. The way of God, the Christian religion, and the Gospel exerted a remarkable influence, flourishing and gaining a large number of followers.
